fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Since \mathbb {Z} is the initial ring, there is a unique ring homomorphism from \mathbb {Z} to \operatorname {End}(A) for any abelian group A. This defines an isomorphism of categories Ab \cong \mathbb {Z}Mod.

fr:title.text: Construction of the tensor product of modules

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Construction of the tensor product of modules

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We give an explicit construction of the tensor product of modules M and N, in two stages. First, when R = \mathbb {Z}, so M and N are just abelian groups, the tensor product is the free abelian group on M\times N, whose elements are written m\otimes n, modulo the relations generated by addition in M and N: m_1\otimes n + m_2 \otimes n = (m_1 + m_2)\otimes n\quad \text {and}\quad m \otimes n_1 + m \otimes n_2 = m \otimes (n_1 + n_2). Next, for arbitrary R, the tensor product is the tensor product of the underlying abelian groups modulo the action of R: (rm)\otimes n = r(m\otimes n) = m\otimes (rn). Alternatively, it is the coequalizer of the two maps M\otimes R\otimes N\rightrightarrows M\otimes N given by acting on M and on N.

A preadditive category is a category enriched in abelian groups with their tensor product. Explicitly, this means it is a category such that each hom-set is an abelian group and composition is bilinear.

fr:title.text: Endomorphisms of an abelian group form a ring

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Endomorphisms of an abelian group form a ring

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: For any abelian group A, the endomorphisms \operatorname {End}(A) of A form a ring, with pointwise addition and composition as multiplication.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The distributive law expresses exactly the linearity of the endomorphisms.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The ring of integers \mathbb {Z} is the initial ring. Explicitly, their underlying set is the integers, with the ordinary multiplication and addition.
Given a ring R, a map \mathbb {Z}\to R must send 1 to the multiplicative unit of \mathbb {R}, and since \mathbb {Z} is generated by 1 this forces the rest of the map.
The category of abelian groups Ab is the full subcategory of Grp spanned by the abelian groups.
An abelian group is a commutative group. Its operation is generally written additively, a + b.
Cat is the category of locally small categories.
A morphism x\xrightarrow {f} y in a category is an isomorphism if there exists an inverse morphism y\xrightarrow {f^{-1}}x such that f^{-1}f = 1_x and ff^{-1} = 1_y, i.e.
commute. If there exists an isomorphism between x and y, we say they are isomorphic and write x\cong y.
